title: Some preliminary responses to responses to the Anti-Reactionary FAQ
summary:
Key ideas:
- Criticisms of the Anti-Reactionary FAQ focused on the author's focus on 50-year social indicators rather than preindustrial village society.
- The author defends this focus by noting that many Reactionaries claim that society was better 50 years ago.
- The author poses key questions about when social indicators changed direction and why.
- The author argues that the dysfunctionality of modern culture is worse for lower-class urbanites and the uneducated; the author suggests the wealthy upper class values should be emulated.
- The author argues that self-respecting men cannot marry sluts.
- The author discusses the flaws of the Cathedral concept.

Key learnings:
- There is a debate about whether society was better 50 years ago or in preindustrial village society.
- Modern sexual norms work better for upper-class suburban whites than for lower-class urbanites and the uneducated.
- People should not marry sluts.
- The idea of the Cathedral has flaws.

Key questions:
- When did social indicators change direction, and why?
- Can the values of the wealthy be exported to the lower class?
- What is the real objection to sluttiness?
- What is the Cathedral?
